div.p: In recent studies, the average capacity for optimal rate adaptation (ORA) of free-space optical channels in turbulent atmosphere has been derived in closed form, mainly based on the application of Meijer's G-function. To this end, the channel was assumed to be memoryless, stationary and ergodic, with independent and identically distributed fading statistics. It was also assumed that scintillations follow a gamma -gamma distribution so as to appropriately describe moderate-to-strong turbulence conditions. In the current contribution, the author will extend this work in two aspects: (i) using the properties of Meijer's G-function, it is shown that the average capacity provides also a closed-form solution for adaptation policies other than ORA, namely optimal power and rate adaptation, channel inversion with fixed rate and truncated channel inversion with fixed rate; (ii) if the additional loss caused by a misalignment between transmitter and receiver (pointing error) is taken into account, it is demonstrated that the developed analytical framework applies straightforwardly.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: For terrestrial distances up to a few kilometres, free-space optical (FSO) communication systems can be a serious alternative to radio-frequency (RF) solutions [1]. This is not only owing to the fact that the former are of low cost, easy to deploy and data-secure, but also because FSO equipment is not limited by regulatory and bandwidth considerations. However, the optical channel is impaired by scintillation effects, that is, fluctuations of the refractive index caused by temperature and pressure inhomogeneities along the propagation path [2,3]. As a consequence, the error performance degrades because of the varying laser beam intensity at the receiver side, which is mainly true for ranges of about 1 km and more. From the statistical point of view, such turbulence conditions are suitably modelled by gamma -gamma distributions [4 -8].

Apart from scintillation effects, the performance degrades also because of building sway [9]. This introduces a pointing error between transmitter and receiver, representing a particular problem in urban areas, where FSO equipment is placed on high-rise structures. Assuming a negligible receiver aperture with respect to the beamwidth, the phenomenon was studied in [10,11]. Farid and Hranilovic focused on a more realistic scenario with non-negligible apertures [12]. In the sequel, their findings were used in [13] to derive the average symbol error probability for onoff keying (OOK) in a K-distributed fading channel.

From a theoretical perspective, the average (ergodic) channel capacity (ACC) is a major figure of merit characterising any communication link. Adopting optimal rate adaptation (ORA), it has been derived in closed form for FSO links in turbulent atmosphere modelled by gamma -gamma distributions, mainly achieved by suitable application of Meijer's G-function [6 -8]. In the current paper, we show that this also holds true for adaptation policies other than ORA [14]: optimal power and rate adaptation (OPRA), channel inversion with fixed rate (CIFR) and truncated channel inversion with fixed rate (TIFR). In this respect, closed-form solutions were already achieved in [15,16] for generalised-K fading channels: note that generalised-K and gamma -gamma distributions are synonymous terms (usually, the former is identified with mobile RF, whereas the latter is more convenient with terrestrial FSO communications). Nevertheless, the results in [15], expressed in terms of Meijer's G-function, are only related to ORA; on the other hand, the derivation in [16] -although addressing the remaining adaptation schemes as well -is primarily based on Lommel functions (the investigated simplifications are of less practical relevance, since one of the shaping parameters must be an integer or an integer plus one half).

Motivated by this background, we will develop in the following a novel and unified analytical framework based on Meijer's G-function, it not only applies to FSO channels modelled by gamma -gamma distributions, but also relates to additional impairment resulting from pointing errors, which would not be possible with Lommel functions or the simplified approach in [16]. In particular, it will be shown that the framework provides closed-form solutions for ORA, OPRA, CIFR and TIFR policies, whether pointing errors are regarded or not. In this context, it is to be noticed that the degradation of the capacity caused by scintillation effects could be mitigated by a spatial diversity concept [17 -19] as well as a properly designed tracking algorithm to compensate for the misalignment between transmitter and receiver [10]; however, this is out of this paper's scope and will be the subject of further investigations.

The rest of the paper is organised as follows. In Section 2, the signal model used for analytical and simulation work is introduced. The focus of Section 3 is on the derivation of the ACC for FSO channels in turbulent atmosphere, both with and without pointing errors taken into account. Numerical results are discussed in Section 4, and conclusions are drawn in Section 5.

div.head: Numerical results
div.p: For all adaptation policies discussed previously, we plot the analytical results derived in Section 3 (lines in different style). For comparison purposes, they are verified by simulation results achieved by the Monte Carlo method (markers in different shape). In this respect, the following parameters are assumed: L ¼ 2 or 7 km for the propagation distance, and C n 2 ¼ 3 × 10 214 or 1 × 10 213 m 22/3 for moderate and strong turbulence conditions; furthermore, the normalised values of beamwaist and standard deviation of the building sway are supposed to be w b /R a ¼ 10 and s s /R a ¼ 0.1, respectively; finally, as typical values for optical wave length and receiver aperture, l w ¼ 1.55 mm and D a ¼ 1 cm will be chosen.

Neglecting the impact of pointing errors, Fig. 1 shows the evolution of the average spectral efficiency (ASE), that is, ASE ¼ ACC/B in bit/s/Hz, for ORA and OPRA policies as a function of the average electrical SNR. As can be seen, the efficiency does not necessarily decrease with increasing values of propagation distance and/or turbulence strength. Not surprisingly, OPRA is superior to ORA.

Using CIFR, Fig. 2 Comparing the curves in Figs. 1 and2, it is clear that, if m is fairly small, the TIFR values are close to those obtained with ORA and OPRA, whereas they start to diverge more and more when m increases.

With the same parameter setting used in Fig. 1, the ASE has been computed by taking pointing errors into account as well. Interestingly, when comparing the results, no substantial discrepancy could be detected to the results achieved with negligible misalignment effects; this is verified in Fig. 4 for all policies (ORA, OPRA, CIFR, TIFR) assuming a less turbulent channel with L ¼ 2 km and C n 2 ¼ 3 × 10 214 m 22/3 . Since the average electrical SNR has been defined differently (it includes the mismatch factor A 0 , when pointing errors are considered), we conclude that the average capacity would just be a shifted version of that without pointing error, if the same definition of m had been applied. The true reason for this remarkable behaviour is that the total loss is assumed as I ¼ I a I p , that is, the multiplicative nature of the random process generates the observed shift. It is to admit that such results would have been expected in case of a constant loss, that is, I ¼ I l I a with I l , 1 so that the fading statistics of I and I a were basically the same, but they were not expected for a probabilistic factor like I p , because the probability distribution of I ¼ I a I p is completely different from that of I a as easily checked by comparison of (3) and (8).

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: A unified analytical framework, mainly based on Meijer's G-function, has been developed to compute in closed form the average capacity for FSO channels in the presence of atmospheric turbulence, with and without pointing errors taken into account. Different adaptation policies were considered in this respect: ORA, OPRA, CIFR and TIFR.

To this end, the channel was assumed to be memoryless, stationary and ergodic, with independent and identically distributed fading statistics. It was also assumed that the channel state information is available at both transmitter and receiver and that the scintillations follow a gamma -gamma model so as to appropriately describe moderate-to-strong turbulences. At a first glance somewhat surprising, it turned out that the capacity with non-negligible pointing errors is only a shifted version of that with no such mismatch; this has been explained by the fact that, irrespective of the selected adaptation strategy, the pointing loss contributes in a multiplicative manner to the total loss.
